newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria bank and food shares rise as oils stumble.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria bank and food shares rise as oils stumble.

text.p: Shares of banks and food companies rose steadily in Tuesday trade at the Nigerian stock market as a fuel scarcity impacted negatively on oil shares, traders said.
The all-share index rose to 7227.45 from 7202.79 on Monday.
Demand seemed insatiable for stocks of the four big banks.
"Investors are active in the banking sector because they expect to benefit from recent directive to banks to raise their capital base," one trader said.
Banks have up to next year to raise their capital base to a minimum of 500 million naira from 50 million naira currently.
Union Bank rose 32 kobo to 7.82 naira, First Bank by 25 kobo to 8.80 naira, UBA gained three kobo to 7.40 naira and Afribank closed one kobo more at 4.16 naira.
Traders said Nestle and Nigerian Bottling Company rose 50 kobo each to 54.50 naira and 35.00 naira, respectively, while Cadbury gained 20 kobo to close at 23.60 naira.
Petroleum shares, usually the toast of the bourse, made token gains because a persistent fuel shortage in Lagos.
Mobil, National Oil and Texaco were each 15 kobo stronger at 55.00 naira, 52.15 naira and 38.15 naira, respectively.
Unipetrol, the highest priced stock on the Nigerian exchange finished 12 kobo higher at 66.00 naira.
The biggest losers were Nigerian Breweries, down 10 kobo at 16.40 naira and Ashaka Cement, 20 kobo lower at 14.20 naira.

Dwindling profitability cost Chemical and Allied Products four kobo at 4.55 naira but Tripple Gee, a computer paper company, dropped 10 kobo to 7.50 naira because investors felt it had reached its peak.
